big_picture_notes: Exodus recounts God's deliverance of Israel from Egyptian slavery and the establishment of the Sinai covenant. The narrative arc moves from bondage and oppression through the liberating plagues, the Passover and wilderness journey, to the mountaintop encounter with the divine and the giving of the Law. The repeated refrain 'I will be your God, you will be my people' frames the entire account as a dramatic revelation of YHWH's sovereignty, power, and commitment to covenant renewal.

stories.story_title: The Deliverer's Genesis: From Bondage to Commission
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with editorial superscription formula ('The words of Jeremiah') transitioning from Genesis patriarch deaths; establishes historical timeframe (627-586 BC) and prophet's Levite pedigree. Ends with Jeremiah's call completion and acceptance, opening narrative mission. Formulaic boundaries: Superscription (1:1-3) signals new genre and era; Call narrative (1:4-19) uses 'word of the LORD came to me' formula marking prophetic authority. Literary glue: Double commissioning (1:1-3 editorial frame + 1:4-19 divine speech) establishes both historical legitimacy and theological calling.

scenes.scene_name: Israel in Bondage: A New King Who Forgot Joseph
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'These are the names of the sons of Israel' establishing continuity with Genesis. Ends with Israel groaning under cruel slavery. Devices: Generational transition; wordplay 'multiplied' (פרה, parah—cf. Genesis 1:28 creation blessing); irony that oppression cannot stop God's promise-multiplication; repetition 'slavery' establishes central problem.

scenes.scene_name: Midwives' Defiance: Fear God, Not Pharaoh
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Pharaoh's genocidal decree against Hebrew infants. Ends with baby Moses preserved, nursed by mother, raised in Pharaoh's house. Devices: Named midwives (Shiphrah='beauty', Puah='splendor') elevate ordinary women as moral agents; 'feared God' (יִרְאָה אֱלֹהִים) vs. 'feared Pharaoh' shows allegiance hierarchy; irony: Nile meant for death becomes instrument of salvation (prefigures Red Sea); typology (Moses in ark like Noah).

scenes.scene_name: Moses Flees: From Palace to Wilderness
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Moses' firsthand encounter of oppression (killing Egyptian). Ends with flight to Midian and refuge at Jethro's home. Devices: Moses' violent attempt shows he cannot deliver by human strength alone; 'looked this way and that' shows he acts without seeking God; Hebrew recognition ('a prince and a judge over us?') previews his future role but highlights he's not yet ready—failure necessary for genuine calling.

scenes.scene_name: The Call at Horeb: I AM WHO I AM
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Israel's cry rising to God ('God remembered His covenant'—זָכַר, zakhar, covenantal action). Ends with Moses and Aaron meeting, accepting commission, performing signs. Devices: Burning bush as symbol of Israel's preservation under persecution (bush burns but not consumed); 'I AM' revelation (אֶהְיֶה אֲשֶׁר אֶהְיֶה) establishes eternal, self-existent identity; God's four 'I will' statements (6:6-8) ground entire deliverance; Moses' objections (adequacy, eloquence, people won't believe) met with assurance and Aaron as spokesman; three signs (staff→serpent, hand→leprosy, water→blood) preview plague complexity.

stories.story_title: The Divine Contest: Pharaoh Hardens His Heart
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with confrontation demand: 'Let my people go' establishing central conflict. Ends with Pharaoh hardened, God's judgment about to commence. Oracle formula structure: Each plague preceded by 'Thus says the LORD' establishes prophetic authenticity. Repetition of hardening pattern (human will + divine confirmation) shows interplay of agency and sovereignty throughout. Literary glue: Intensifying pattern (water→frogs→gnats→flies→livestock→boils→hail→locusts→darkness→death) creates escalating tension toward climax; separation formula (4:22-23) between divine contest and liberation begins.

scenes.scene_name: Let My People Go: Pharaoh's Defiance
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Moses and Aaron's demand before Pharaoh ('Let my people go'). Ends with Moses' bitter prayer: 'Why have you brought trouble on this people?' Devices: Pharaoh's response 'Who is YHWH? I don't know him' frames entire plague sequence as revelation of God's identity; increased workload (straw removed, quota unchanged) shows oppression intensifies before deliverance—tests faith; Israel turns on Moses showing faith-community's fragility.

scenes.scene_name: The Ten Plagues: Signs of YHWH's Supremacy
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with reassurance formula 'I am YHWH' (God reveals covenant name in response to despair). Ends with death of firstborn threatened, redemption price established. Devices: Plague pattern (warning→execution→consequence→Pharaoh's response→hardening) repeats to demonstrate God's control over nature and Egypt's false gods; plagues target Egyptian deities (Nile=Hapi, frogs=Heqet, livestock=Apis, darkness=Ra) showing YHWH's supremacy; separation motif ('I will make distinction...Goshen untouched') establishes covenant protection; hardening language shifts from Pharaoh-active (7:13, 8:15) to YHWH-active (9:12, 10:20) showing God confirming Pharaoh's choice for demonstrative purposes.

stories.story_title: Liberation to Liturgy: The Passover Redemption
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with Passover institution ('This month shall be the beginning of months'—new calendar marking liberation). Ends with Israel crossing Red Sea safely, enemy destroyed, Song of Moses proclaiming YHWH's victory. Central chiasm: Bondage (Egypt) → Deliverance (Passover) → Wilderness crossing (Red Sea) → Liturgical commemoration (Song). Formula markers: Passover covenant formula ('I am the LORD...I will redeem you'—6:6) reappears in liberation narrative establishing continuity; blood/protection motif (doorpost blood→Red Sea crossing→Song) unifies entire section theologically.

scenes.scene_name: The Passover: Death of the Firstborn and Redemption
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with detailed Passover instructions (lamb selection, preparation, eating, haste). Ends with Egyptian pursuit into Red Sea. Devices: Passover as counter-creation (darkness 12:30 vs. light 12:37, death of firstborn vs. generation birth); blood on doorposts creates theological space of protection; Pharaoh finally concedes ('You and your flocks will die'); eating ritual while fully clothed (readiness for journey) establishes perpetual memorial; Egyptian plunder fulfills God's promise (3:21-22, 11:2-3) that Israel leaves with provisions; Red Sea crossing (14:21-29) is re-creation parallel (waters divide like Day 2, dry land emerges like Day 3) with YHWH's ruach hovering (1:2 parallel).

scenes.scene_name: The Song of Triumph: God's Eternal Victory
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Moses' song ('I will sing to the LORD...') proclaiming deliverance. Ends with Miriam's refrain ('Sing to the LORD!') and the women's celebratory dancing. Devices: Poetic victory hymn (qinah meter parallels lament reversed to triumph); repetition of 'horse and rider thrown into the sea' creates rhythmic hammer; theological theme: YHWH's 'right hand' (arm imagery) saves Israel just as it struck Egypt (2x); mythological language ('Who is like you among the gods?') asserts YHWH's unparalleled power; women's participation (Miriam as prophet-musician) validates female prophetic leadership established by midwives.

stories.story_title: Liminal Space: Testing and Provision in the Wilderness
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with wilderness journey ('three days in the desert without water'). Ends with Jethro's visit affirming God's deliverance and Moses' leadership. Liminal theology: Space between Egypt (past bondage) and Sinai (future covenant), physically designated 'wilderness' (מִדְבָּר, midbar—a place of divine testing and providence). Pattern: Need (thirst/hunger) → complaint → YHWH's provision (spring/manna/quail) → instruction. Narrative movement: Marah (bitter water), Elim (oasis), Wilderness of Sin (manna), Rephidim (water again, Amalek battle), Sinai arrival. Theological glue: Each provision miracle answered with torah-instruction (Sabbath law 16:4-5, cultic regulations 16:31-35, covenant law 18:20) preparing community for formal covenant at Sinai.

scenes.scene_name: Water from Stone: Murmuring and Faith Tests
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with wilderness travel and thirst complaint. Ends with water from Horeb rock and people's question 'Is the LORD with us or not?' Devices: Repetition of pattern (need→murmuring→provision→praise) establishes learning cycle; bitter water (מרה, Marah) becomes sweet with wood (tree foreshadows cross in later tradition), etiology explains location name; manna (מָן, man='what is it?') and quail provision are supernatural bread and meat paralleling future Eucharistic imagery; Sabbath law (double manna on sixth day) establishes commandment within provision (foreshadows Sinai); water from rock (17:1-7) at Massah/Meribah (testing/strife) establishes place-name etiology; narrative emphasis 'Is the LORD with us?' shows deepening faith-community relationship.

scenes.scene_name: Amalek's Attack: Spiritual Warfare and Intercession
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Amalek military assault. Ends with Moses' altar 'YHWH is my Banner' and declaration of perpetual war. Devices: Joshua (יְהוֹשוּעַ, Yehoshua='YHWH saves'—first mention) leads military; Moses' intercession on hilltop with Aaron/Hur supporting (prefigures priestly role) shows prayer as spiritual warfare parallel; raised hands (עַל־הַנְשִׁי, al-hanishi='upon the banner') wordplay on banner-God (cf. v.15); Amalek becomes perpetual enemy (Deut 25:17-18) representing recurring resistance to God's people.

scenes.scene_name: Jethro's Counsel: Wise Administration of Justice
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with Jethro's arrival with Zipporah and Moses' sons. Ends with administrative restructuring into judges/officers. Devices: Zipporah's return (from 4:25 circumcision context) symbolizes family reconciliation before covenant; Jethro's Midianite blessing ('Blessed is YHWH...') shows pagan priest's faith conversion; observation of Moses judging all disputes shows leadership breakdown; administrative wisdom (appoint rulers of thousands/hundreds/fifties/tens) prefigures later 70-elder structure (Num 11:16-25); this section establishes communal governance structure necessary before formal Sinai covenant—shows leadership structure supporting individual relationship with God.

stories.story_title: Sinai Covenant: God Dwells with His People
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with YHWH's covenant formula 'Now therefore, if you obey...you will be my treasured possession' establishing conditional relationship. Ends with covenant written on stone by God's finger and placed in ark, sealing YHWH's presence. Theophanic structure: Preparation (19:1-15)→Theophany (19:16-20:21)→Law (20:22-23:33)→Covenant ratification (24:1-18). Formula markers: 'These are the words' (דברים, devarim—cf. Deuteronomy name) frames law collection; 'the voice of YHWH' (קוֹל יְהוָה, qol YHWH) repeated throughout theophany establishes God's word as central; 'blood of covenant' (דַּם הַבְּרִית, dam habberit—24:8) seals relationship through sacrifice. Chiastic structure: A: Theophanic descent (19:16-20)→B: Law (20-23)→A': Covenant confirmation with God's written word (24:1-18).

scenes.scene_name: The Theophany: God Descends Upon Sinai
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'In the third month...' (two-month transition from Egypt) establishing covenantal timing. Ends with people at mountain base trembling, Moses alone ascending. Devices: Mountain preparation (abstinence, sanctification, boundary-setting) establishes holiness protocol; theophanic signs (thunder, lightning, thick cloud, trumpet blast, mountain shaking) create overwhelming sensory experience showing God's transcendence; three-day preparation (19:10-15) parallels death/resurrection pattern; 'I will come to you in a thick cloud' emphasizes divine accessibility within transcendence.

scenes.scene_name: The Decalogue: Ten Commandments as Covenant Foundation
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'And God spoke all these words' (direct divine speech, no mediation at this point). Ends with people's fear and request that Moses mediate. Devices: Ten-word structure (מִצְוָה, mitzvah='commandment') becomes canonical; first four commandments (God-focused) precede last six (neighbor-focused) showing vertical relationship foundation; repetition of name YHWH (יְהוָה) in first person throughout emphasizes God's identity and authority; Golden Calf interruption (22:30-23:33) provides legal elaboration and conditional covenant language ('if you listen...you will be my people').

Starts with God's instruction 'You have seen...I have spoken' establishing legal authority. Ends with angel-promise of Promised Land conquest. Devices: Case law structure (אִם־תִשְׁמְרוּ, im-tishm'ru='if you hear/obey') links obedience to blessing; laws cover ethics (masters/servants, violence, theft), religious practice (Sabbath, feasts, firstfruits), and social justice (widows, aliens, poor) showing covenant comprehensiveness; angel-mediation (23:20) prefigures post-Sinai guidance; wilderness-to-land trajectory established.

scenes.scene_name: Covenant Ratification: Blood Seal and Glory
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with 'Come up to the LORD, you and Aaron, Nadab and Abihu' (hierarchical approach). Ends with Moses entering cloud for 40 days receiving stone tablets. Devices: Covenant meal (eating/drinking before God—24:11) symbolizes fellowship; 'blood of covenant' (כְּפֵי הַבְּרִית, kepi habberit—v.8) seals commitment—Moses sprinkles half on altar/half on people creating sacrifice-mediated relationship; 'written with God's finger' (24:12, וּכְתִיבִים בְּאֶצְבַּע, akh'tebuim be-etsba) connects to plague language ('finger of God'—8:19) showing revelation continuity; 40-day period establishes extended prayer/instruction time (prefigures 40 days wilderness testing, 40-year wandering).

stories.story_title: Pivotal Breach and Presence: Idolatry, Forgiveness, and Tabernacle
stories.why_start_end_and_literary_glue: Begins with 'When the people saw that Moses delayed coming down from the mountain' establishing breach-moment. Ends with 'And the glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle' establishing restoration. Central irony: While Moses receives law on high, Israel violates it below (golden calf). Narrative arc: Breach (32:1-6)→Judgment (32:7-35)→Intercession (32:11-14, 33:12-34:9)→Restoration (34:29-35:39). Theological resolution: God's presence (שְׁכִינָה, shekhinah) returns not through perfect obedience but through forgiveness and covenant renewal (34:10, 'I am making a covenant'—renewed after breach). Tabernacle construction (35-40) transforms tent-of-meeting into portable Sinai, bringing holy presence to community's center. Inclusio: 'I will dwell among you' (25:8, 29:45-46)→'The glory of the LORD filled the tabernacle' (40:34-38).

scenes.scene_name: The Golden Calf: The People's Rebellion
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with impatience ('Moses delayed coming down'). Ends with feast celebration before calf. Devices: Aaron's enablement (collecting gold without resistance) raises priestly complicity questions; calf described as עֵגֶל, eigel (young bull—Egyptian Apis imagery) connecting to plague-judgment themes; 'These are your gods' (plural despite singular object) shows covenant-law violation within 40 days of ratification; 'feast to the LORD' (24:5-level language misapplied to idols) demonstrates theological confusion—shows people creating manageable deity.

scenes.scene_name: Moses' Intercession: Covenant Renewal and Forgiveness
scenes.why_start_end_and_devices: Starts with God's threat 'I have seen this people...I will consume them' (comparable to Sodom destruction language). Ends with covenant renewal ('I am making a covenant before all your people'—34:10). Devices: Moses' intercession (תְּפִלָּה, tefillah—prayer as bridge) appeals to God's name-reputation and promise to Abraham ('Remember your servants'); destroyed tablets (32:19) show covenant-rupture physicality; second tablets (34:1) written by God again showing grace; 34:6-7 revelation of God's character ('compassionate and gracious, slow to anger, abounding in loyal love...') becomes foundational confession (quoted throughout OT); Moses' radiant face (קָרַן, karan—'horns/rays') becomes permanent sign of encounters with glory.

Starts with Sabbath law reminder (35:1-3) establishing order-restoration. Ends with cloud/glory filling tabernacle and pillar of fire guiding journeys. Devices: Detailed specifications (ark, table, lampstand, altar, courtyard) allow community participation (freewill offerings—35:21-29) making tabernacle collective creation; construction completion (40:33-37) literally fulfills covenant promise 'I will dwell among you'; God's glory manifests physically (cloud by day, fire by night) providing divine guidance and presence comfort; portable sanctuary design allows presence to accompany wilderness pilgrimage—Sinai experience becomes traveling revelation. Final imagery: Moses cannot enter tabernacle because glory fills it—shows divine holiness even after breach/forgiveness, maintaining transcendence within immanence.
